rooms.name: The Keep Entrance
rooms.description: The winds here are tempestuous, on this short walkway.  You barely keep your balance as you struggle to its end.  Once there, you stare in awe at the huge double gates that guard this imposing citadel.  The keep itself is the size of a city, with stone walls that stretch toward the sky.  The hinges of the gates are the size of a man's forearm, made of some bronze-colored material.  Mists swirl around the top of the keep's pure white spires; you see lightning crash above your head, though sunshine also spills to the ground.  Statues of gargoyles and winged angels adorn every available cornice and balustrade. Inside here, Lokari, God of the Moonless Night, makes his home. Do you dare enter Lokari's Keep alone? Do you dare enter it with a pack of friends? You thought you were brave enough, but now...

North.description: A hall floored in pure white alabaster goes to the north.

extras.text: The gates are an indication of the keep itself-- huge, imposing, metal-studded and metal-laced through wood so hard you can't scratch it with anything you have. You can open these gates, you think, if you have a lot of help. Most likely your adventure through the Keep will be very similar.

rooms.name: The Alabaster Hall
rooms.description: You find yourself standing in the center of a beautiful white hall.  The floor is polished alabaster that reflects your own image up at you.  The walls are carved friezes of the same stone, images you can't comprehend: strange people, fantastic beasts, machines of enormous size and unknowable function. The images scroll all around you, except for the archway to the south and the doors to the east and west.

East.description: An alabaster door carved with beautiful men and women stands to the east.

South.description: The Keep gates stand a short way to the south.

West.description: A beautiful door made of cast gold, carved fantastically, stands here.

rooms.name: Timun's Tragic End
rooms.description: This dark, imposing room is lit by a single red flame scintillating from a large red gemstone suspended from the room's ceiling.  The haunting shadows illuminate a black stone coffin in the room's center.  The dancing red light barely illuminates a tapestry against the far wall.  This, and the flame, are all that can be seen in the room.  An archway leads northward.

North.description: You see a dark hall to the north.

rooms.name: The Hall of Deaths
rooms.description: This long, dark hall is barely illumined by tall, standing torches set into each corner. Once one adjusts to the light level, one can see the various horrible murals carved and painted on the walls. The artistry displayed is incredible, but the fiendish imagination is no less than diabolical. Battles, sacrifices of both humans and objects, and twisted renditions of Lokari himself in victory over the wreckage of vast hosts lie on every wall. Scenes of torture lie near the archways themselves, each more detailed and anatomically correct than the last. Archways lead to the east, south, and west. A large statue stands against the north wall.

East.description: A dark hall stands to the east.

South.description: A dark hall stands to the south.

West.description: A dark hall stands to the west.

Down.description: The floor looks quite plain and unremarkable.

extras.text: The trapdoor set into the floor is made of thick, ancient oak wood.

The statue is of a man in terrible agony, a little hunched over from some great pain in his belly. He holds his arms to his stomach, as if to keep his innards inside it. He looks upward, his mouth opened in a soundless, eternal scream. On his forehead is written, terrible in its simplicity, MEZU, THE FIRST GOD TO FALL Those who look very closely at this statue will see the pentagram-shaped indentation in its side.

rooms.name: Rhalean's Cruel Finish
rooms.description: Murals all around this almost-dark room show a tall, ordinarily- serene goddess shackled screaming to one bowl of an antique-looking balance.  Water drips slowly into the other bowl.  The goddess' eyes are fixed above her, to the giant sword waiting to impale her helpless form as her end of the scales tip upward.  The Goddess of Justice will die by her own scales of justice.  A stone coffin in the center of the room is carved with the scales of justice, but the scales in the carvings are broken into hundreds of pieces.

East.description: You see a dark hall to the east.

rooms.name: Azkrael's Brutal Demise
rooms.description: This almost-dark chamber is large, and painted in a background of dark green murals of forests. The scent of rotting meat is strong in the air, and those who seek its source quickly find that it is coming from the middle of the room, from a marble pool. A human-looking woman is crucified to a tree growing from the pool. Her face reveals the agony of her last moments, and her body is almost completely destroyed by the fangs and claws of wild beasts. Her pitifully mauled form glows just enough to illuminate the murals of the chamber. The Goddess of the Hunt was destroyed by her own hounds, in this vision. A stone coffin is barely visible through the waters of the pool at the figure's feet.

West.description: You see a dark hall to the west.

Down.description: The central sarcophogus is lidded with a thick plate of stone.

extras.text: The coffin is made of stone. It lies at the bottom of a shallow pool of water that just barely covers its lid.

rooms.name: The Alabaster Hall
rooms.description: Your footsteps echo on the milk-white floor.  All around you you see evidence that you are indeed in the home of a god-- the elegant murals on the walls, the statues standing along the walls, the finials set into the corners of the ceilings, the mosaic floor made of all kinds of different shades of white formed into subtle patterns.  But every once in a while you see something that makes you shiver-- some of the statues look like they're in agony.  One of the mural scenes on the walls depicts a tall, powerful-looking man gesturing fire down upon a walled city.  One of the murals is a pentagram.  Just every once in a while, you notice something that goes against your preconception of what a god's home should look like.

East.description: You see a staircase made of gleaming alabaster to the east.

West.description: A large white alabaster door, carved with beautiful men and women and reinforced with gold, stands here.

rooms.name: The Alabaster Stairs
rooms.description: The elegant milk-white staircase arches above your head to unknown glories and perils.  The steps are inlaid with tiny chips of differently-shaded alabaster in patterns.  One step is in the patterns of waves, another in little starbursts, and so on, all the way up.

North.description: A bit of loose paneling is evident upon closer examination.

West.description: The alabaster hall runs off to the west.

Up.description: Bright white sunlight pours down on you from the white carved stairs.

rooms.name: The Chamber of Exaltation
rooms.description: A single table in the center of the room.  A single golden vase on the table.  A single cream-colored rose in the vase, its leaves green and vibrant against the otherwise almost-white room.  You look around in wonder-- the simple beauty of this room is taking your breath away!  The sunlight pours in from the east.  Tapestries line the walls to the north, in a great hall.  A doorway to the south, carved gold and alabaster, completes the image.

North.description: You hear silence to the north.

East.description: A garden path goes off to the east.

South.description: A wooden door with no doorknob stands here.

rooms.name: A Velvet Lined Hallway
rooms.description: Thick velvet tapestries line both sides of this long hallway.  Your fingers, brushing against the velvet, don't stir up any dust, although you have the clear impression that these curtains have been here for a long time.  When you push on the curtains you feel hard stone beyond them.  The tapestry is woven into beautiful patterns, each step forward more fascinating than the last.

North.description: The hall continues to the north.

South.description: A beautiful chamber stands to the south.

extras.text: The velvet is woven into patterns: Suns, moons, planets, and on each wall, a beautiful, well-muscled man in a flowing red cloak, his hands outstretched through his private cosmos, swirls of light shooting from his fingertips. But his eyes look very cruel. You understand at a glance that this must depict Lokari, and you're not sure you want to see him now.

rooms.name: A Velvet Lined Hallway
rooms.description: The hall's floor is shiny, from ages of being polished over and over again. The click of your shoes is muffled by the thick velvet curtains along each wall, though.  The beautiful images in the velvet tapestries hold your attention as you walk through.

South.description: The hall continues to the south.

West.description: At first glance you don't notice anything out of the ordinary.

extras.text: The velvet tapestries depict a powerful godlike man who spins planets from thin air and sets them in motion, whirling amidst suns and stars. The entire effect is unearthly, and intended to be so. You don't even understand everything you see here. But when you push on one of the tapestries, to the west, you can feel it give a little. You do notice a tiny hole in the tapestry-- a keyhole, perhaps, but whatever key opens it would be so thin it wouldn't resemble a key at all.

rooms.name: The Contemplation Chamber
rooms.description: It's quiet in here.  Even your soft breathing echoes loudly in this dimly lit chamber.  A torchiere lit with a red flame burns at a low level, throwing dancing shadows onto the walls.  A cushioned footstool just low enough to kneel on stands before a short wooden railing.  Perhaps it's some kind of prayer pew. Before the railing, at eye level to whomever knelt at the footstool and railing, is a footstool cushioned in velvet.  It doesn't look like it's been used for very long-- the velvet isn't worn anywhere you can see.  That, or Lokari, the owner of this Keep, doesn't feel the need to kneel in supplication terribly often.

East.description: The thick red curtain hides the back of a tapestry.

West.description: An evil-seeming altar stands to the west.

extras.text: The curtain reveals the back of a tapestry -- rough and nubby from weaving. Near its edge, you detect a hole in the wall -- a very small hole. It is decorated, making you suspect that it is supposed to be there. But if it is a keyhole, the key must be very long and thin indeed.

rooms.name: The Altar of Revenge
rooms.description: This large room is walled and floored entirely in black marble. An ebon altar stands at the northern end of the room. Black glass urns stand upright on the top of the altar, with smoke issuing from each one's narrow neck. The smoke rises eerily to the ceiling, which is black tile held in by weirdly warped branches of some kind of black tree; the branches wend their way across the entire ceiling in a grotesque pattern. Horrifying friezes are carved into all walls of the room, all depicting torture and pain. The most obvious way out of here is a handsomely-appointed and much less intimidating chamber to the east, visible through an archway.

East.description: You see a quiet chamber to the east.

South.description: The horrible carved frieze has a pentagram-shaped flat indention in its surface.

Down.description: You detect a dusty circle in the floor.

extras.text: The friezes line the walls. They're intricate carvings of people, demons, beasts, horrors you are convinced came out of your worst nightmares. The carving is all the more remarkable because it's done in the deep black wood of the rhell tree, which is almost impossible to carve well. But then, as you look, the southern wall seems to be a little different...

It is made of black marble, simple and elegant, being a simple rectangular shape with rimmed edges. A few things are set on its surface in what appear to be deliberate placings -- a stone knife with a few flecks of dried blood on its edge, and an elegant silver chalice set with gems and runes. No mortal may touch either of these; any attempts will burn the hands badly.

rooms.name: A Garden Path
rooms.description: You walk in a dew-covered garden path.  The path is made of little white stones pressed into the moist, lush earth of the garden itself.  Even though you know, rationally, that you're inside the Keep, you can't believe how convincing this path is.  You honestly feel like you're inside a beautiful palace garden.  Above your head, birds sing.  To the north, you see a pool of some kind.  To the west, glass doors open to the Keep's interior.  To the east, the garden continues, passing near a tall, narrow stone structure about your height.

North.description: You see a pleasant little pool to the north.

East.description: A short structure of some kind stands to the east.

West.description: You can re-enter the Keep to the west.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take the high road!

rooms.name: The Dovecote
rooms.description: Most nobles in ancient times kept a dovecote to raise pigeons in.  This one is a magnificent example of its genre: a very tall almost-building made of stone, with a small gate at its bottom and hundreds of holes a bird could fly into.  It smells vaguely of soap and feathers, as if someone has been trying valiantly to keep it clean.  The flutter of hundreds of wings is audible inside it.  You could just about fit into the little double doors, if you tried.  You can go west, to a beautiful garden path, or to the north, to a wishing well, or south, further along the path.  East of you, the sunshine falls full across a beautiful patio of some sort.

North.description: You see a well to the north.

East.description: You see a beautiful veranda to the east.

South.description: You see a garden path to the south.

West.description: The path continues to the west. Beyond that, you see the Keep.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take to the air!

rooms.name: The Wishing Well
rooms.description: As you come into this part of the garden, you feel care and worry lifting from you like old, worn garments.  A beautiful, innocent-seeming well stands nearby, with the path going up to it and circling around it.  It's a low well, low enough that you can put your hands onto its edge and look down into its cool watery depths.  You see coins glinting below, but you can't reach in to get the coins.  The well is made of alabaster and marble, with an arched roof above it kept up by marble pillars carved with angels.  You resist the urge to toss a coin in.  To the south, you see a stone structure of some sort.  To the north, a large glass building sparkles in the sunshine.

North.description: A clear glass wall, fogged with steam, has a door set into its side.

South.description: A short structure stands to the south.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take to the air here.

rooms.name: The Crest
rooms.description: The vista here is glorious!  You step lightly from the garden path of the lush green garden onto a white-tiled veranda that juts out from the mountain's steep side.  You could have a ballroom dance on it, if you wished.  A low stone wall rises along the circular curve of the veranda.  Angels carved of white marble perch along the wall at intervals.  You approach the wall, careful lest the footing be insecure-- though it seems quite solid-- and gasp with wonder as you look across the most breathtaking panorama you've ever seen.  The mountains stretch before you, shrouded in sweet white mist, while wildwinds sweep across you, tickling your nose with the scent of clean mountain air and some kind of flower.  The dizzying heights seem to pull you into a neverending mental freefall.  You step back a little, awed and exhausted.  You can go north or south to see the Hanging Gardens, or west through the garden again.

North.description: Magnificent hanging gardens spread northward from here.

South.description: Magnificent hanging gardens spread southward from here.

West.description: A short structure stands to the west.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take to the air above you.

rooms.name: The Blackness
rooms.description: You spin, flailing your arms as you struggle to get re-oriented.  You can see absolutely nothing in here, not even your hands in front of your face when you raise them, incredulous.  There is no way up.  You can only go further down.

Down.description: You can't see a thing below you, but it's the only way you can go.

rooms.name: The Blackness
rooms.description: You spin downwards through the longest pit you've ever seen.  You can't even see your own hands in front of your face!  You flip head over heels, your equilibrium gone, and your mounting sense of dread increasing with every foot you fall.

Down.description: You can't see a thing below you, but it's the only way you can go.

rooms.name: A Foul Pit
rooms.description: This wretched prison hole is utterly black, with fetid air that assaults the nostrils. The walls are coated in a horrible slime that might once have been mildew. Worst of all, from the darkness, the bodies of those who fell before can be made out, still rotting in their armor, and sometimes a faint snuffling sound can be heard. There are no exits.

rooms.name: A Primrose Path
rooms.description: And now here you are walking down a primrose path!  Will your morals never improve?  -- But it is a pretty part of the garden.  Lush green shrubs and trees compete with the grass for the sunshine pouring from above.  The sheer array and variety of the flowers you see astounds your eyes and your nose, for yes, they smell heavenly.  Here and there small colorful birds flit around the flowers.  Hummingbirds and dragonflies zip past you, so bright they reflect the light like little mirrors on a mountaintop.  Above you the air seems to dance. To your north and east, the garden continues.

North.description: A short structure stands to the north.

East.description: The perfume of hundreds of different flowers wafts to you from the east.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take to the air here.

rooms.name: The Hanging Garden (S)
rooms.description: Lokari's famous hanging garden is reknowned throughout the world as one of the Wonders of the World.  And these are magnificent gardens.  All manner of hanging plants seem to float in the very air, suspended by marble pillars carved into fanciful shapes-- birds perched on columns, angels with swords of fire, intricate shapes found nowhere in nature.  The flowers and herbs that spill out of the various containers thus suspended from the slim golden chains defy your imagination in their beauty.  Lokari's got great taste in horticulture, that's for sure.  You wander through, enjoying the sweet vista that is barely visible to the east.  You could stay here, if you wished, or you could go north, to the veranda.

North.description: You see a veranda to the north.

West.description: A garden path goes off to the west.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take to the air from here.

rooms.name: The Hanging Gardens (N)
rooms.description: You find yourself on the northern end of one of the Seven Wonders of the World: the Hanging Gardens of Lokari.  The end of this veranda is obviously not suited to an actual garden with soil, so Lokari ordered a garden that would be safer to install.  And this is it.  Marble pillars carved into animals and angels and shapes from nature (and far removed from it) support all manner of bowls and planters, in all sizes and shapes, suspended from slender gold chains that glint in the sunshine.  The flowers explode from everywhere at once-- ones you recognize from your own homeland, and others that seem more exotic than anything you've ever seen.  Herbs, some flowering, some lush and green and without flowers, pour out of other containers.  Plants are banked along manmade terraces, as well.  It smells wonderful here!  You can go south, to the veranda, and if you could fly, you could go upwards, to the dancing air.

South.description: The veranda comes to a crest to the south.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take to the air here.

rooms.name: The Greenhouse
rooms.description: You push open the glass door, and catch your breath at the heat and humidity in here.  As you trudge further into the greenhouse, you begin to feel more and more like some very wet and very furry animal is sleeping on your chest.  But it's quite beautiful.  You have to admire the sheer order that must be present here.  Shelves -- one above, one below -- ring the greenhouse, breaking only for doors.  On the shelves, all over, are carefully marked plants.  Some are seedlings, some growing, some obviously weather-injured.  You may go west, to another room in the greenhouse, or south from here, or up to the crawlspace above your head.

South.description: A glass door set into the greenhouse bars your passage.

West.description: It's even warmer to the west.

Up.description: You can climb up into a crawlspace here.

rooms.name: The Hothouse
rooms.description: It's hotter and more humid in here than you thought it'd be!  You blink through sweat to see a riot of color like you've never seen before!  All along this beautifully crafted glass enclosure are plants, gloriously flowering. Orange and red, blue and purple, yellow and white, compete uproariously.  The scent of fine flowers, like perfume, seems almost overpowering, with the clean scent of fresh-turned earth.  You can go only east, back to the greenhouse proper, or up to the roof through a small door.

East.description: The greenhouse continues to the east.

Up.description: You can climb up onto the hothouse roof from here.

rooms.name: A Wading Pool
rooms.description: You come upon a pretty little scene in this beautiful garden-- a shallow pool surrounded by hand-sized grey and reddish rocks, worn smooth from time. Yellow narcissus and yellow-and-purple hyacinth and red pansies line the bank of the pool, except where the garden path goes up to it.  There you see a small stone bench, set right up at the water as if inviting you to dangle your bare feet into the water.  While the thought is pleasant, your brow darkens at the idea of being thus defenseless.  You can go south from here, back to the garden.

South.description: A cool garden path leads off to the south.

Up.description: If you can fly, you can take to the air here.

rooms.name: The Hall of Wonder
rooms.description: As you pass through this hall, you do indeed wonder.  The walls are inlaid with colored stones to form a magnificent mosaic that depicts fabulous sea-monsters that rise and fall through the endless oceans to destroy cities, continents, and, of course, men.  One figure rises, that of a beautiful woman with long, flowing hair dark as the night, to oppose one of the beasts, her hand in that of a man with skin pale as milk, who flies near her.  The hall itself is not very long.  Your feet echo on shining floors, bouncing off the mosaic'ed walls.  West lies what is clearly another beautiful part of the hall. Eastward lies a door.

East.description: A golden carved door stands here.

West.description: You see another hall to the west.

rooms.name: The Ballroom Foyer
rooms.description: A short turn in the hall, yes, but it's beautifully adorned with mosaics of stars and suns in gold and indigo in swirling patterns that catch your eye at every step.  Truly, you are in the home of a god!  You can go north, to a magnificent ballroom, or east, to the hall's continuation.

North.description: The ballroom begins to the north.

East.description: Another hall begins to the east.

rooms.name: The Ballroom (W)
rooms.description: You stand in a beautiful ballroom.  The ceiling is so high you have to squint to see the angels and stars painted on the ceiling.  A huge glass dome atop the ballroom is so crystal clear you can see everything outside, though it'd have to be strong enough to hold up the roof, of course.  You can't imagine why Lokari had this ballroom constructed, though it is beautiful.  As you walk across the shining white floor, taking in the banners hanging on the walls, the stained glass windows depicting heroes and heroines of ancient days, you begin to piece together the mystery that is Lokari.

East.description: The ballroom continues to the east.

South.description: A hall begins to the south.

rooms.name: The Ballroom (E)
rooms.description: The floor is polished white marble so fine you can see your reflection in it.  The ceiling is far above your head, painted in glorious angels and astronomical themes, inset with a massive clear glass dome that magnifies starlight and sunlight both, you know already.  The echo of your feet on the floor bounces off long banners sewn with care, depicting every device you've ever heard of from every major house in the ancient world, hanging from a golden rail that goes all around the room, about ten cubits from the ceiling. Between the banners are stained glass windows, backlit to better show their scenes of heroes and heroines of the ancient days, their weapons flashing, their hands glowing with powerful spells, haloes behind their heads.

West.description: The ballroom continues to the west.

Up.description: In one corner, you notice a metal ladder. A small gate bars your way.

rooms.name: The Alabaster Stairs
rooms.description: The top of this gleaming white staircase defies description!  You step lightly on the shiny, almost slippery white surface, its slickness expiated only by the deep carvings in its surface that depict stars, suns, moons, and patterns, carvings that make the footing somewhat surer.  The staircase railing glides past your fingertips, smooth oak polished until it, too, shines.  The railing's struts are made of carved marble somehow inlaid with more of the ancient brown oak.  The staircase ends in a terrace, or you can head west to a hallway.

North.description: Past the staircase, you see a terrace.

West.description: Glittering gems to the west catch your eye.

Down.description: The glistening white staircase continues downward.

rooms.name: A Gem-Encrusted Hallway
rooms.description: Your fingers brush against such a casual display of wealth.  Your eyes widen at the sight of such beautiful, bright gems being used for what seems frivolous decoration.  Of course, Lokari is a god; he is theoretically able to get as many riches as he wishes.  The gems are set into the wall mosaic-style, as if the chips in the wall are only fancy stones.  Amazing!  You can go west, to a quiet side room, or east, to a gleaming white staircase's landing.

North.description: A gold-chased oaken door stands here.

East.description: A staircase made of alabaster begins to the east.

West.description: You see a quiet seeming room.

rooms.name: A Tower Cupola
rooms.description: This must be one of the Keep's towers.  You step into its foyer, looking out beyond the filmy silk gauze curtains that flutter between you and the great outdoors.  As you push them aside, you blink, your eyes adjusting to the vista before you.  The tower rises far above the ground, swept by the wind winds that assaulted you on the way here.  Before you, to the south, lies the Elemental Plane of Air, the winds roaring and whispering and caressing and threatening and assaulting.  You shiver at the thought of braving that place.

North.description: You can't see much for the sunlight here. It's a little dark.

rooms.name: A Reading Room
rooms.description: Maybe Lokari has a good side.  If he does, it's nowhere as evident as it is here.  A quiet, almost restful nook greets your eyes.  Most of the gentle light in here is filtered through the silken curtains of the cupola terrace to the south.  White candles in golden sconces along the wall provide the rest. Bookshelves full of tooled leatherbound books and enamel-capped scrolls line the west wall and every other place that's got enough room.  In the center of the room rest two chairs, both overstuffed leather.  Between them is a small table with a single shelf, supported on lion-clawed legs.  On the table is an oil lamp full of sweet-smelling oil.  In one corner of the room is a podium on which rests a large, thick book that smells vaguely of aged parchment.  It looks like a dictionary, though in a language you can't identify right offhand.

North.description: You see a small room through a wide open door.

East.description: A gem-encrusted hall starts to the east, and beyond that, a gleaming white staircase.

South.description: Dazzling sunshine pours in from the south.

rooms.name: A Drawing Room
rooms.description: The room is a little dim, but not impossibly so.  Your feet tread expensive, deeply piled carpeting nervously.  Comfortable chairs are arranged throughout the room.  A fireplace stands inexplicably against one wall, though the embers are cold-- no fire has been set here for quite a while, you'd venture to guess. The walls are adorned by paintings in frames of gilded wood.  None of the pictures seems to have been selected by anyone with real artistic sense.

North.description: You see an unadorned room with a wooden floor.

South.description: A room full of bookshelves lies past a wooden archway.

West.description: One of the tapestries hides a panelled door set into the wall.

rooms.name: The Hoard Room
rooms.description: Your eyes almost bug out of your head at the treasure in here!  Chests full of coins, gems, jewelry of every description, sceptres, all gleam as with their own inner fire.  Compared to other rooms in the Keep, you find this room rather plain, except for its contents.  A thronelike chair sits in the center of the room on a furry white bearskin rug.  A few chests sit very close to it. Lokari must like to visit his hoard room!  One thing that catches your eye is a delicate diamond and sapphire tiara.  As you reach for it, it mists right through your fingers.  You wonder where the real tiara is.  It's fit for a princess.

North.description: A simple wooden door stands here.

South.description: A simple wooden door stands here.

rooms.name: The Terrace
rooms.description: This room is wide, sunny, and sweet, with lots of glass windows enclosing a sort of patio.  The floor, polished wide, square black stones, is almost bare of furnishings.  A wicker chaise lounge covered in soft cushions rests beside a glass-topped wooden table.  As you look outside the windows, you see the garden stretching out below, with mountains beyond.  You wish you could rest here, but your task is not yet done.

North.description: A glass-paned door is set into the wall.

East.description: You see the open air to your east.

South.description: A staircase made of gleaming alabaster stands to the south.

rooms.name: Dreaming of Irinia
rooms.description: You suppress a shudder as you enter this small room.  Inside it is a shrine to the mortal woman Lokari wanted for his own, and whose soul he eventually captured by foul magicks.  A full-length painting of her adorns one entire wall, all by itself, lit by wall sconces with black candles in them, adorned further by ivy trailing around its wooden frame.  She looks magnificent, a beautiful, strong woman.  Her muscled frame is set off perfectly by a gown fit for a queen.  Around the rest of the room, you see more paintings and personal effects-- a lock of raven-black hair bound by a long silk ribbon, a necklace a child might wear, a small treasure-box of inexpensive rings.  The most chilling thing in the room, however, is a large painting opposite the full-length one that obviously depicts the princess and Lokari together on what must be their wedding day.  You are chilled to the bone, looking at it.

East.description: An ebon door stands here.

rooms.name: A Quiet Room
rooms.description: You step through the entrance onto a polished wood floor.  This room doesn't look like it belongs in the Keep.  It's understated, with no hangings, no paintings, no ornaments.  The only thing in here, in fact, is a wall sconce. On the sconce rests a wall shelf, just one shelf mounted on the wall.  On the shelf sits a plain marble candleholder, with a plain, medium-length black candle in it.  The candle is lit.  Your blood chills, though, when you notice that the candle looks brand-new, as if it had never been lit, but the warmth from the flame permeates the entire area around the sconce, as if it had been lit for hours.

North.description: You see what seems to be a servant's room through the doorway.

South.description: You see a drawing room.

West.description: A black wooden door stands here.

rooms.name: In the Chamber of a God's Bride
rooms.description: What does a god's bride's chamber look like?  Why, this, of course.  The white-painted walls produce a large chamber, guarded over by alabaster carved angels at each corner on little ledges.  Ferns and ivy plants surround each angel.  The ivy drips to the floor, the deep green striking in the sunlight pouring in from thick glass windows set into the east.  One tendril of ivy almost touches the lions-claw foot of a large fourposter bed standing in the center of the room.  The bed looks large enough for six.  Its brass headboard and footboard is blocked by thin white gauze curtains that extend all the way around the bed.  More ivy, with fuschia flowers, snakes around the rails between each post of the bed; the curtains fall from these rails.  You're amazed at the pure luxury.  The shiny white floor holds little else.  A wooden armoire stands against the western wall, locked against all attempts to open it.  Shelves set into the northern wall hold all manner of girlish treasures-- little glass bottles, bath salts that make the room smell like heaven, cleverly carved figurines of exotic hardwoods, a jewelry box that, when you open it, seems to have nothing in it. You have to admire Lokari. He might be pretty vicious, but he seems to have a gentle side.

North.description: You can swish the white curtains aside to reveal a wooden door.

East.description: Magnificent double doors stand to the east.

South.description: A golden door stands to the south.

rooms.name: The Bedroom of the God of the Moonless Night
rooms.description: You step into this room and feel almost dizzy.  Where does a god sleep? Anywhere he wants.  Lokari's power and dominion are nowhere as evident as in the place he reposes at night.  The room is floored in what looks like hematite-- shiny grey-black stone.  A thick indigo rug is thrown on the middle of the floor.  A massive bed stands in the center of the huge room.  The frame of the bed is in purple heartwood, a deep mauve stain making the wood shine. It's carved in blackberry brambles.  The bedcoverings are in crimson.  The walls are of a dark red wood, carved all along their length in more blackberry vines, leaves, and berries, each berry stained dark purple, all the way up to the ceiling, which has a skylight set into its center.  The light that comes down wreaths the bed in light and illumines the wall sconces set into each corner of the room.  Each sconce is made of gold, with ebon candles that are unlit.  You can go north, to his bath chamber.

South.description: A prettily painted door with glass tiles is set into the wall.

West.description: A gold-wrought door stands here.

rooms.name: The Virgin Bath
rooms.description: You enter a voluptuous room, and immediately don't wish to leave.  Sunlight pours in through a huge window with one single pane-- amazing!  -- set into the east wall.  The sunlight dances around a bathtub large enough for six people to relax in.  A portable step rests next to the bathtub.  The sunlight darts around the tub's lion-claw feet, briefly touching an elegantly carved golden pail with a steel handle before moving on to a low shelf of books and pretty glass bottles of oil.  The sunlight flows through the glass bottles, making the colored oils within shine with vibrant flashes of color.  The flashes of color, so like stained glass, hit a golden pitcher whose function is not immediately obvious, but which sits on a golden tray next to two beautifully hand-blown wine goblets.  The shadows of the goblets touch the wall opposite the windows, where ivy and flowering plants grow right up the wall.  The ivy crawls across the ceiling, to the opposite side, framing the windows.  All in all, a beautiful scene.  The only way out is a door to the south.

South.description: The voluptuous chambers of the God of the Moonless Night beckon.

rooms.name: The Maidservant's Chamber
rooms.description: It's a small room, and not very fancy.  Obviously, it belongs to a servant. The feminine print on the bedspread, as well as two threadbare dresses in the open closet, tell you the room must belong to a maidservant.  But what's this? Under the thin pillow on the bed you find a note, but it's tattered beyond recognition.

South.description: The door to the south is painted in bright patterns of leaves, trees, and birds.

West.description: You see another servant's room to the west.

extras.text: You carefully unfold the aged paper, smoothing out the brittle creases. Some of the yellowed paper splinters off in your hands, making you wince. Your eyes scan the browned ink, but you can't read the neat, precise handwriting's alien words. Finally you refold the paper and put it back under the threadbare pillow. You straighten up, still thinking about the letter. Obviously, someone cared enough for the contents of the letter to keep it all these years. But who? And why?

rooms.name: Severan's Chamber
rooms.description: You walk in, and immediately understand what Lokari did.  He must have invited Severan here, to the Keep, to serve him and his new bride, Severan's former love, Irinia.  Severan, of course, would have refused vehemently.  But this room must have been where Lokari wanted Severan to stay.  It's quite well appointed, with rich hangings on the walls, a comfortable-seeming bed, several large, fluffy pillows, and a velvet bedspread embroidered with something in a foreign-looking script, a short word you can't read.  Shelves are lined with books, most of them in that same script, but one has a title you can read: "Techniques of the Polar Guard Squad: Triple Attack in Thirty Days!" It's quite thick.

East.description: You see another servant's chamber.

South.description: You see a plain room to the south. More rooms lie beyond it.

rooms.name: The Catwalk
rooms.description: You stand on a precarious-seeming metal grating catwalk that extends over the ballroom below.  It looks like it'd extend a good dozen paces toward the center of the ballroom, just about reaching a central chandelier.  You suppose the catwalk makes cleaning the glass chandelier a lot easier.  The openweave metal of the catwalk, though, makes footing precarious!  You can feel it wobbling with each step.

East.description: A chain-link and wooden door stands here.

Down.description: A metal plate covers a ladder near the top of the metal ladder.

rooms.name: The Hothouse Roof
rooms.description: You almost sneeze in the musty air up here.  Not only is it musty, it's moist, dank, almost wet.  You open a panel and are outside on the roof of the hothouse, balancing precariously and hoping desperately that the glass on the roof is a lot stronger than it looks.  The sun seems much brighter here than elsewhere; perhaps it's magnified by the glass.  The sparkling-clean glass winks up at you.  You can go east, through a panel, to a neighboring greenhouse, or south-- if you can fly!

East.description: The crawlspace continues to the east.

South.description: You see the tips of garden trees for quite some distance.

Down.description: You see thousands of colorful flowers below you.

rooms.name: The Crawlspace
rooms.description: You creep up a small ladder slowly, feeling your way.  Below you, the warmth generated by hundreds of growing plants makes this crawlspace almost unbearably hot.  It's also rather dark, making you feel distinctly uneasy about putting your hands anywhere.  Already you're touching things that make you queasy.. Living things..  Soft living things..

West.description: You can keep going west if you wish.

Down.description: You see the greenhouse below you.

rooms.name: Above a Sparkling Pool
rooms.description: You fly free above the beautiful Keep gardens.  Below you is a shallow wading pool.  A glass wall rises to your north, and the mountains loom far to the east.

North.description: You see the roof of the hothouse.

East.description: The top of the garden spreads out to the east.

South.description: The top of the garden extends to the south.

Down.description: You see a wading pool below you. How pretty!

rooms.name: Above the Well
rooms.description: It's so peaceful here.  Floating above the little garden well below you, with soft breezes caressing your face and body, you can almost believe that no evil exists in the world, and that you're at perfect peace.  It doesn't last, though.  You look around and see that you can go east or west, by flying, or head back down to the well.

East.description: The hanging gardens invite you to enjoy their peace.

West.description: The top of the garden extends to the west.

Down.description: Below you, you see a wishing well.

rooms.name: Above the Hanging Garden
rooms.description: You hover near a terraced garden.  Numbers of terraced shelves go right up the wall of the garden.  Plants of every description spill out of the shelves in carefully manicured explosions of color.  You look down and see the path that winds around the garden.  You can go down, west, or south.  It's so beautiful here, though, with the mountains so close by.

South.description: You can fly south, to hover above the crest of the veranda.

West.description: You can see the entire garden spreading to the west. It's so green!

Down.description: Below you, you see where the hanging gardens begin.

rooms.name: Above the Crest
rooms.description: The view here is magnificent!  You look around joyfully.  Here you are free, for the first time in your life.  Tears come to your eyes when you behold the utter simplicity of your position.  You hover, Lokari's gardens to your back, and behold the mountains, rising like giants as far as your eyes can see, fading from reddish to brown to purple.  The winds are quite strong; the voice of the winds is a haunting melody that sobers your exultation eventually.

North.description: You see the hanging gardens.

South.description: You see the hanging gardens.

Down.description: Below you is seems like a nice place to stand while looking out over the mountain vistas.

rooms.name: The Dovecote's Upper Half
rooms.description: You are instantly revolted by the smell of caged birds.  Your hands slip a little on the ladder you climbed, and you very happily stand on your own two feet, glad to get away from the encrusted ladder.  The birds might be beautiful and elegant outside this dovecote, but inside it, they're absolutely disgusting.  The dovecote itself is spacious and bright, with light filtering in through small bird-sized holes all through the structure.  It's made of some sort of cement, you guess, that's been molded into a kind of tower.  It's almost beehive-shaped.

Down.description: Birds' cooing assaults your ears below-- and what a SMELL!

rooms.name: Above the Gardens
rooms.description: You hover above a beautifully manicured garden.  It's so peaceful up here, with breezes warm against your body, ruffling your hair.  The mountains rise to the east, and a huge Keep to your west.

North.description: The top of the garden lies to your north -- and beyond that, a building's roof.

West.description: You can enter a terrace to the west.

Down.description: Below you is the beautiful garden path of Lokari's Keep.

rooms.name: Above the Garden Path
rooms.description: You hover above a beautifully manicured garden.  A white path slashes through the green like a beam of pure light made solid.  Ancient statues dot the walkway here and there.  But up here, you can only see a few treetops, can feel only wind caressing your body.  The mountains rise to your east, and the Keep to the west.

East.description: You see the hanging gardens.

Down.description: You see a path winding through the huge gardens below you.

rooms.name: Above the Hanging Garden (S)
rooms.description: You hover above a beautiful hanging garden.  Terraced steps rise to where you float, with plants flowing out of the terraces and out of numerous pots that hang down from the terraces by hooks and light golden chains.  Flowers of every variety explode in color.  You reach out to touch something very pink, and startle when it shrinks and shrivels at your touch.  A moment later, unmolested, it expands and unfolds into a flower again.  You look around.  You can go north, west, or down to the lower level of the garden.

North.description: You could go north for a beautiful view of the mountains.

West.description: You see the top of the garden to the west.

Down.description: Below you is a pretty garden path.

rooms.name: The Dungeon Entrance
rooms.description: You look around at the dismal chamber.  Your spirits do not improve after the first glance.  It's very dark, barely lit by candles in sconces every ten feet or so along the wall, about shoulder level.  The walls and floor are roughly hewn stone, tunneled right into the mountain the Keep is on, you think. Weird howls sometimes fill the air.  You can't tell if they're from living -- or dead-- souls.  You can go upward again, or to the east.

East.description: You see a dismal cell block to the east.

Up.description: Above you, you see where the trapdoor is set into the ceiling above you.

rooms.name: A Cell Block
rooms.description: You walk past a row of cells carved into the tunnel wall.  Thorned iron bars stand between you and the cells' interiors.  One of the cells' doors is locked by a powerful-looking padlock, but you can't see anyone inside, just a dirty skeleton.  You shiver and move on, keeping a good eye on the insides of the cells.  An unearthly moan fills the air.  You feel the hairs on the back of your neck rise, as if in eerie salute.  You can go east or west from here.

East.description: You see a guardroom to the east.

West.description: You see the entrance to the dungeon to your west.

rooms.name: The Guard Room
rooms.description: A small corner room connects two cell clocks.  Sparsely decorated, you see a table with two wooden chairs pushed under it.  On the table, you see a deck of cards, divided into two piles, one in front of each chair.  Something forced the guards to leave in a pretty big hurry.  You wonder what.

North.description: A cell door stands to the north. Its padlock looks very strong.

South.description: An iron-work wall closes off the southern part of the room.

West.description: A narrow corridor leads to a cell block.

extras.text: As you examine the wall, you admire its absolute blackness. You reach out and touch it, and your hands almost sink into its colorless depths before you touch the cold wrought iron. The iron is thorned, so you're very careful not to prick your hands. The darkness seems to consume the entire wall. How will you open that darkness?

rooms.name: The Dark Cell
rooms.description: You walk into death, of that you are sure.  You can't see a thing, and your hands, questing in front of you, touch bare dank stone, with just a hint of moss and lichen.  You recoil in disgust.  You can go north, only north.

North.description: The darkness roils to the north. You can barely see beyond it.

rooms.name: A Cell Block
rooms.description: You walk past a short row of cells set into the wall.  There are about three cells.  They all look alike-- small, dank, dark, with a small pile of hay in one corner, no windows, thorned iron bars, iron gates.  You shiver within your armor as you walk past them.  It's as if ancient misery can reach out to you and touch you.  You can only go south, but the east is blocked by rubble.

East.description: To the east, a bit of rubble seems loose.

South.description: The gate to the south is locked with a huge padlock.

extras.text: The path looks like it was destroyed by a cave-in. One boulder in particular looks pretty key. If you could just move it, you might be able to clear the rest of the rubble.

rooms.name: A Raw Stone Tunnel
rooms.description: You crawl through a narrow tunnel that seems thick with choking dust and loose dirt.  You clamber to your feet, all too aware of how vulnerable you are in this cloying darkness.  You take a short, shallow breath, trying not to breathe in too much of the dust all around you.  You can head east from here. The passageway west is choked with rubble.

East.description: A creepy tunnel opens to the east.

West.description: To the west, you see the rubble that blocks this tunnel.

rooms.name: The Place of Skulls
rooms.description: You stand in the center of what is obviously a ceremonial place of the dead. Shelves hewn from the mountain itself hold polished, gleaming white skulls. Each skull's macabre grin seems to cackle obscenely at you.  You fight a shiver as you walk through here.  An altar built of bones stands here, as well, but it holds no answers for you.  You can go east, further into the catacombs, or south.

East.description: You see dark catacombs.

South.description: A large, dark cavern greets your eyes. You can see little detail in its depths.

rooms.name: Catacombs
rooms.description: Here, in tunnels hidden from the world for who knows how many generations, you can feel the veneration and the quietness that only the grave seems to engender.  It's dark, with just a little light filtering in from an unknown source, just enough that you can pick your way through the tunnels with relative ease.  Shelves built into the rock hold things you suppose the dearly departed held dear: a book, open to a passage in an unknown language; a battered stuffed animal made of tattered red fur; a dress made of white linen, ironed and laid out as if its wearer de-materialized while lying down.  All of these things, a dozen perhaps in all, one on each stone shelf, combine to make this entire room quite eerie in nature.

South.description: The Catacombs continue to the south.

West.description: A rough-hewn stone tunnel begins here.

rooms.name: Catacombs
rooms.description: You walk through a room full of stone shelves, about three high and bunked against the walls.  There are about twelve shelves in all.  Each shelf is wide enough, and long enough, and sturdy enough, that you could lie down on it, though you'd never want to do that-- you're jumpy enough without inviting the comparison to a corpse.  Each shelf has something on it.  Looking closely at one of the shelves, the object looks like it's a pretty wooden box.  You could open the box, but you don't.  Every little noise makes you startle, as if a skeletal hand were about to reach out and touch you.  A shudder runs down your back.  You can go north, through another part of the catacombs, or south, to perils unknown, or west.

North.description: The Catacombs continue to the north.

South.description: You see signs of human life to the south -- thank goodness!

West.description: You shiver at the sight of skulls lining stone shelf after stone shelf.

rooms.name: An Encampment
rooms.description: You're amazed!  Hidden in the depths of the catacombs is what's obviously a soldier encampment of some sort.  Some of the shelves have been roughly hewn off from the walls.  In their place, you see sleeping pallets and a cooking fire.  Rocks surround the fire at a comfortable distance for enjoying a warm blaze during what must be freezing nights.  You pick your way through the encampment carefully, not willing to call attention to yourself this early, at least not before you find out more about who lives here.

North.description: The narrow, cramped tunnels of the Catacombs start here.

East.description: You see the beginning of a newly made tunnel to the east.

South.description: You see canvas tents, cookfires, and weapons of all kinds littered about -- clearly, this is a military encampment.

rooms.name: A Newly Made Tunnel
rooms.description: You carefully walk through a tunnel.  But not just any tunnel.  This tunnel has a new look about it.  Its walls aren't blackened by soot given off by innumerable torches and candles.  The dust that tickles your nose is the dust of newly moved earth, not the dust of ancient settling rocks.  You wonder how long this tunnel has been here, and who made it.  You somehow doubt the owner of the mountain knows it's here.

South.description: You gasp when you see the sky outside through a cave mouth.

West.description: You see an encampment to your west.

rooms.name: A Cave Mouth
rooms.description: You breathe in the free air that suddenly rushes at you like a living thing. The tunnel opens up to become a wide-mouthed cave.  As you head out of it, you're suddenly about to fall right down the mountainside!  You windmill your arms, flailing wildly while you regain your balance.  You look down, very glad for your good reflexes-- you would have surely died on the way down, as unexpected a fall as it was.  You look around, looking for some way out.  You think you can see a way to climb up the mountain a ways, to a marble balustrade about fifty paces above your head.

North.description: A newly-hewn tunnel begins to the north.

Up.description: There is a marble balustrade above you.

rooms.name: The Dark Prison
rooms.description: Your feet stumble a little; at first you can't tell why, in the near-total darkness.  Then, as your eyes adjust to the almost-nonexistent lighting, you see that the floor is made of flat, square granite stones that have crumbled with age and moisture.  Mosses peek through the stones here and there.  As you pick your way through, you can see that you are in what is obviously a prison of some kind.  Thorned iron bars stand in a row to the west, marking off a cell of some kind, but no one is in it.  You look upward, to the stairs.  They don't look very sturdy, suddenly.

South.description: You smell blood and fear in the darkness to your south.

Up.description: Your hands can't find any purchase in the ceiling above! What is holding you from going up?

extras.text: As you examine the iron bars of the cell, you notice that off to the side, there's an ingenious lockbox hidden in the shadows of the dank room. You examine it closer, and see that the box itself is actually a covering for a simple lever device. The lever leads to a series of pulleys and iron bars set against the ceiling.

rooms.name: A Torture Chamber
rooms.description: You pick your way across the broken granite stones of the floor, your stomach twisting at the sight of the torture instruments laid out on the tables and low ironwork shelves all along the walls of this chamber.  You can't even imagine what some of these implements are for, and you don't want to!  The room is pretty dark, and the blood you see congealed here and there on the instruments is old blood, dark brown and dried.  You turn away in distaste and look for exits.

North.description: You see the entrance to this wing of the prison.

East.description: You see a dark, narrow hallway.

South.description: A horrible smell comes from the south. What is there?

West.description: A stone door reinforced with metal thorns stands here.

rooms.name: The Dark Hall
rooms.description: You pick your way carefully across dank, rotting granite floorstones.  Moss makes your footing slippery and uncertain, and the stench of decaying stone and warm earth and death combines to produce a stink that's almost worse than just rotting bodies.  You can go north or west from here.

North.description: You see someone's living quarters through an open archway.

West.description: You see a torture chamber to the west -- and you shiver.

rooms.name: The Torturer's Suites
rooms.description: Did you wonder how a torturer lives?  You can see that here is where Lokari's Master of Pain must live.  An ornate four-poster iron bed stands in one corner.  You walk to it idly, almost not noticing the thorned headboard and footboard.  You notice a strand of long, blonde hair caught in one of the thorns of the headboard and restrain yourself from looking at the bed further. Paintings in beautiful gold frames depicting stars, moons, and other features of the night sky line all the walls in a precise line.  A tall cabinet holding various kinds of liquors stands against one wall.  The walls are painted deep blue.  A thick, dark blue carpet lines the floor.  An ironwork bookshelf takes up another corner all by itself.  You blush to read the books' titles. Torturing people pays pretty well, you decide.  This room is lusciously appointed.

South.description: You see a dark, narrow hallway to the south.

rooms.name: A Warm Tunnel
rooms.description: You find yourself in a stone-lined tunnel that reeks of pain, blood, and raw earth.  You can't figure out why it's so warm, though.  The ceiling creaks under the sheer weight of what's above this floor, and you begin to desperately hope that the entire cavern won't cave in...

East.description: A stone door reinforced with metal thorns stands here.

South.description: A heavy wooden door stands here. The picture of a sun, shining brightly, is etched into its surface.

rooms.name: The Necromancer's Den
rooms.description: Keeping up with the undead is a full-time job, you suppose, as you look around.  Why would someone want to live in a cavern, unless he just liked being around his creations more than around the living?  The floor is bare stone, though better kept up than elsewhere in the cavern, and covered here and there by throw rugs that look warm.  A simple wooden bed with a headboard stands against one wall.  The headboard is simply carved with geometric designs.  Two bookshelves stand sgainst the south wall, filled to bursting with books that are piled into it with little attention to detail.  A plain wooden desk in a corner is stacked with books and papers.  Your curiosity is piqued, but, alas, you cannot read the language the papers are written in.

North.description: A heavy wooden door stands here. Etched into its surface is the outline of a sun.

West.description: A solid-seeming oak door stands here. A picture of a set of scales appears burned into its surface.

rooms.name: The Feeding Room
rooms.description: You step into a dark, high-ceilinged cavern.  It's dark, shielding you effectively from what you are sure is a horrifying sight.  It smells like something died in here a long time ago.  It smells wet and rotting and fleshy and slippery, and you fight to keep your last meal in your stomach where it belongs.  And then, you suddenly become aware of a pit right under your feet! You scramble for solid footing.  Will you make it in time?

North.description: You can leave this place of death by going north, to a forbiddingly gruesome torture chamber.

Down.description: Even from up here you can hear the dreadful growling coming from below.

rooms.name: Irinia's Sorrow
rooms.description: You realize that you stand in what is unmistakably a prison cell that has been inhabited for a long, long time-- perhaps centuries.  The identity of that inhabitant, or inhabitants, is painfully and quickly obvious.  A cruel, decaying stone floor, the dank feel of moist rock walls, foul straw in one corner, a ragged bit of cloth piled on more straw in the opposite corner, stand in stark contrast to an elegant ermine robe hanging on a golden hook along the back wall.  The sight of the robe is so jarring you almost don't notice it. The cell doesn't seem to support anyone living anymore.

North.description: The door is plain oak, with a symbol burned into its surface-- that of a horn...

East.description: A solid-seeming oak door stands here, a set of scales burned into its surface.

extras.text: The ankle-length robe is made of very heavy crimson velvet damask, lined with dark-spotted white ermine fur. It looks beautiful, clean, utterly new, and it's such a blazing contrast to the rest of its surroundings you can't figure out how to categorize it. Why is it hanging here, as if to underscore the misery of its surroundings?

rooms.name: Lokari's Wrath
rooms.description: The cell door to the south opens into this chamber, so horrifying you wish you could faint, just to get the images out of your mind.  A thorned iron rack stands above a cold forge.  An iron maiden stands against one wall, its spiky embrace cool to the touch, waiting for whom it might still entrap.  The marble-tiled floor is spotted in places with dark brown blood that never came clean.  An elegant blackwood chair with lion-claw feet stands near the forge, as if a royal observer wished to observe someone's agony.  You shudder, unseen fingers tracing your spine.  Shackles hang from heavy wooden beams set into the ceiling; they brush your shoulders as you walk by them, making you feel vaguely filthy.

North.description: You see a run-down cell to the north.

South.description: A solid oak door stands here. A picture of a horn is etched into it.

rooms.name: The Chamber of the Ladies in Waiting
rooms.description: The dedication of the ladies in waiting to their ruler is painfully evident in this room.  It's a large prison cell, its stone floor rotted long ago to crumbles of loose rock that threatens to trip you at any moment.  Windowless, cheerless, malevolent, its only concessions to kindness are the straw pallets in the corner, enough for, you'd guess, three or four people.  But the pallets appear unused.  The straw piled beside the pallets looks like where the people in this cell actually slept.  Could it be, you wonder suddenly, that the people in this room chose to go without the primitive beds?  Why would someone do that?

South.description: You can feel the power emanating from the cell to the south -- whose is it? What secrets will it reveal?

rooms.name: The Lair of the Beast
rooms.description: You tread lightly in the bottom of what your senses tell you is a long, narrow pit.  You recoil with horror at the smell, a thick, oily, coppery scent mixed with animal waste and sheer terror, a palpable scent.  You cringe internally at the sight of the dimly lit pit's bottom, littered with red-streaked bones, torn and shredded clothes, a lock of long golden hair, snagged on the corner of a metal helmet...

Down.description: You think you can move these boulders aside.

rooms.name: The Soldiers' Quarters
rooms.description: You wander into what is clearly a place for military people of some sort to camp out.  The tents are clearly military issue of some kind.  Someone, probably Lokari, controls this operation and gave out these supplies in the name of his war.  But why are the the soldiers still here at all?  The only war you know of involving Lokari was that waged against him by Severan and his legions, and that was generations ago.  You pick your way through the primitive stone floor, aware that you are in terrible danger to be penetrating this far into the encampment.

North.description: You see the encampment to the north.

South.description: This must be where the camp's inhabitants store their foodstuffs.

West.description: A cavern with a very high ceiling opens here.

rooms.name: The Soldiers' Training Ground
rooms.description: The ceiling here is very high above your head, forming an unforgiving rock cavern large enough for the small arena in its center.  You walk toward the arena formed by wooden planks into a circle.  Sand fills the arena to an ankle-deep depth.  The sand looks clean and cool, though you don't dare touch it and face that distraction.  The arena is large enough for a few people to get in and fight, with lots of standing room around for spectators.  From you, you can see only an east exit.

East.description: The living quarters of the army lie here.

rooms.name: An Ancient Battleground
rooms.description: You happen into a rather odd cave.  At first you thought it was just an outcropping, but now, you can see that it's far more than just an accidental bit of cave.  You gingerly thread your way past past broken boulders and dusty rocks, peering into the near-total darkness at the wonders you behold. Clearly, this was at one time the site of a major battle.  Broken weapons and armor lodged under rocks glint back at you.  Scars on the wall bespeak a time when spears and swords rang out in battle.  Now, though, it's hushed, quiet, almost reverent.  The only exit is north.

North.description: You're horrified to see skulls sitting atop dozens of stone shelves.

rooms.name: A Storage Cave
rooms.description: Even an encampment must have a place to put supplies.  This is obviously it for this one.  Large jars stand against the wall.  You go to one, and see that it's empty, and has been for some time.  Sacks of grain that's clearly moldy are piled against another wall.  Potatoes that are sprouting sickly green shoots pile into another corner.  It doesn't smell very good, though it does remind you of how good a home-cooked meal really is.

South.description: A porphyra in the corner lies against the wall. Its lid is loose.

extras.text: To say it's a large jar isn't doing it justice. It's a HUGE jar with a pointed end. The lids are fitted on tightly, with hooks carved into the stone of the lid itself, for hanging the entire jar up. Since there's nothing in this jar, or its mates, there seems to be no reason to hang them up. They look extremely sturdy. Their plainness just emphasizes their utilitarian nature. The one you're most interested in is lying right at a place in the wall where the mortar of the wall is partially eaten away. The jars, being human-sized, are far too large to pick up, and your efforts to smash them are repelled -- they're too sturdy. Perhaps you need something magical to help you destroy them..?

rooms.name: A Narrow Corridor
rooms.description: You've broken into a narrow corridor.  It's nearly dark, though that's no surprise, since most of the Keep seems to be nearly dark.  You wander down the corridor, wondering what seems to be so different about this particular hall, when it hits you.  The floor.  It's in excellent condition.  You can feel the sturdy stones under your feet; the masonry is uncorrupted by time or the moisture of the rock.  From here, you can go south, back to the entrance hall. A door blocks the way north, but you can also crawl up, though you can't tell what's above this hall.

North.description: The door has an unusually shaped keyhole-- hammer-shaped.

South.description: The corridor opens up into an entranceway.

Up.description: A fetid stench greets you from above your head, where a trapdoor lies.

rooms.name: The Entrance to the Holding of the Jann
rooms.description: A glorious hall, a beautiful entranceway; you stand in awe.  Somehow the narrow, dark corridor to the north has opened into this well-lit, elegant foyer.  The floor is white alabaster stone, and polished to a shine that reflects you back at yourself.  Fluted pillars support the high, white ceiling. Carvings are lavished on every available surface-- animals, designs of every sort, angels, demons, gods...  All looking down at you as if expecting you to do something.  A dark corridor goes off to the north, and there is a guard post to the west.

North.description: A dark corridor goes off to the north; beyond that is only darkness.

West.description: You see a guardpost to the west. Hopefully the guards are friendly.

rooms.name: An Underground Guard's Post
rooms.description: You stand in front of a relatively plain white marble structure.  Tall, narrow windows face all directions of the hall-- east and south.  A stool stands pushed against a wall, as if its owner had to get up in a hurry.

East.description: You see a gleaming entranceway to the east.

South.description: You see a courtyard to the south, well-kept and manicured.

rooms.name: An Underground Courtyard
rooms.description: A beautiful underground river flows up here, bubbling a short distance before it flows back into the heart of the mountain.  Around it, someone has arranged a beautiful man-made pond of sorts to catch the excess streamwater. Vibrant green water-plants and water lilies stand around and float in the pond, which is small enough that you could jump across it.  Statues are arranged around the pond, short white marble statues depicting various animals in stylized form that are far enough apart that you can easily walk around them for a better view of the stream and pond.  Alabaster pots holding dark green ferns and small trees stand at the edge of the courtyard, near Doric columns that stretch all the way to the white ceiling.  Numerous wall sconces holding lanterns, golden sconces, provide more than enough light.

North.description: You see a small guardpost to the north.

South.description: You see a shining white room to the south. In the room's center you see a stone bowl on a pillar. What is this?

West.description: You see an elegant receiving room.

Down.description: A symbol carved into the floor catches your attention.

extras.text: As you look at the golden plate in the floor, you realize you can't decipher the arcane symbols carved into it. They seem to center on one particular part of the plate. You look closely at the plate and see that it has a hole in it! Well, at least the hole is intentional. You push at the plate, but it clearly wants something more than just a push.

rooms.name: The Jann Chief's Receiving Room
rooms.description: An elegant room greets your eyes.  A red and gold carpet rolls forward to a sumptuous (and, incidentally, extremely comfortable-seeming) gold-chased chair. Red enamelled pots, filigreed with gold and gems, stand on either side of the chair, ferns exploding out of them, surrounding the area around the chair. Cream-white columns add support for a high white ceiling.  Tapestries and paintings adorn the walls.  You wander around, impressed.

rooms.name: The Room of Sights
rooms.description: You enter a fabulous room constructed of shining white stone of some kind. Light seems to suffuse this room from sources unknown.  Redwood and purple heartwood entwine in elaborate designs along the tops and bottoms of the walls. In the center of the room stands a small stone bowl supported by a short pillar.  The bowl comes to about waist height.  Clear water fills the carved white stone bowl.  Carved ivy leaves run down the pillar.

extras.text: The bowl and pillar are made of matching alabaster stone, carved with ivy leaves and polished until they both shine, reflecting the sourceless light. When you look into the bowl, you are shocked to see scenes of all four elemental planes: roiling water, rushing winds, licking flames, set against dark stone.

rooms.name: The Altar of Sending
rooms.description: You stand in the center of an eight-pointed star, worked in mosaic in the middle of an otherwise white marble floor.  The cardinal points of the star are worked in gold, while the other points are in silver.  Each gold point points to a gateway.  You can sense power in this otherwise utterly plain room, power and a sense of responsibility.  You wonder why the people who created this room had need of it.  Obviously, it's important, but how?

North.description: You see the Gateway to the Elemental Plane of Earth.

East.description: You see the Gateway to the Elemental Plane of Fire.

South.description: You see the Gateway to the Elemental Plane of Air.

West.description: You see the Gateway to the Elemental Plane of Water.

Up.description: Above you, a short flight of stairs ends in a trapdoor marked with mystic symbols.

rooms.name: The Gateway to the Earthen Realm
rooms.description: You stand in the middle of a room hewn straight from living rock.  The beautiful white floor of the room to the south ends as if it melted clean away, revealing a stone floor.  The raw rock walls seem to stretch away from a centerpiece that depicts a mountain on a pedestal.  Bonsai plants are set into the miniature mountain in a classical cascade pattern.  If you feel brave, perhaps you can explore the Elemental Realm of Earth?  The gate that stands before you beckons.

North.description: The gateway is held shut by a padlock.

rooms.name: The Gateway to the Plane of Water
rooms.description: The white floor of the room to the west stops and you have to step down into a shallow pool of water that extends through the entire chamber.  You notice that the water seems perfectly pure, and unnaturally light blue, as if it were deeper than it really is.  In the center of the room, a fountain of water bubbles cheerfully.  The droplets arc through the air and fall in glittering splashes of prismed color, falling against an elaborately carved gate.  You are enchanted with the peacefulness of the scene and watch for a moment.  You realize this room could send you straight to the Elemental Plane of Water.

East.description: To the east, you see the Altar of Sending.

West.description: The glittering gateway ahead is held shut by a padlock.

rooms.name: The Gateway to the Plane of Air
rooms.description: Howling winds pull you and push you in every direction.  You walk with effort to the center of this room-- or close to it, anyhow, because the center of the room is taken up with a very deadly-looking tornado whose source you can't identify.  It's not moving, so you surmise it's not natural in origin. You can't even see the edges of the room you're in-- you can't see very far at all in this fog.  When you read forward, you can feel a forbidding stone gate just ahead of you.  But you are sure that you are in a gateway, and that you could reach the Elemental Plane of Air from here.

North.description: To the north, you see the Altar of Sending.

South.description: The stormy gateway ahead is held shut by a padlock.

rooms.name: The Chamber of the Jann Chief
rooms.description: Far from the opulence and indulgence of the receiving room, this room seems practical and almost homey, as if the Lord of the Jann were far too humble a man to bother with frills, but has to show them for the benefit of others.  A simple table covered in maps and instruments stands in the center of the room. A leather curtain hides a simple wooden bed from straight viewing.  You feel a sense of sympathy for the mysterious Jann chief, just from seeing that he's a person of simple tastes.

East.description: To the east, you see the Jann lord's receiving rooms. Beyond that, you see an opulent courtyard.

rooms.name: The Gateway to the Realm of Fire
rooms.description: The room is ablaze!  You cry out in surprise, then in pain, staying as far away from the center of the room.  A downdraft of fire, a column of flame, seems to well up from the center of the room, consuming everything in the room. You hear a crackling that would indicate that there's some kind of fuel feeding this fire, but you can't see it, nor would you wish to try to investigate-- the heat is so incredible you can barely squint.  But through it all, you can barely detect a gate ahead.  Where does it go to?  Perhaps to the Elemental Realm of Fire, as you thought when you came here?  Do you dare?

East.description: The gate is held secure by a strong padlock that you cannot break.

West.description: To the west, you see the Altar of Sending.
